friend1

One of the things I try to show people is that abortion and personhood has no one right answer. Religious groups find themselves in the debate almost everywhere and in many cases; it is religious groups that are major advocates or opponents for abortion. Looking around, I have seen that many religious arguments are diffused through different threads and that there is a lack of views from many groups. I think it might be beneficial to all if these arguments are together on one thread as a reference point. I hope persons of the different faiths of the world would post the viewpoint of their religious practice. I would post some views from the HINDU perspective. (Not all Hindus may have the views below and may even have more information to share.)
 
 Hinduism: 
 
 Some may say that collectively, Hindus are divided on the abortion issue. Some aspects of scriptures are against abortion (based on personhood). Examples against abortion:
 1) Bhagwat Purana : In this text, Sage Kapil relates to his mother the various stages of development. His description, especially what happens in the seventh month of pregnancy clearly shows an unborn child as a being.
 2) In many Puranas, the tale of Prahalad is related and how as a child in his mother's womb, he can be considered to be a distinct being.
 3) The basic principle of Ahimsa.
 
 But there are some arguments that may support abortion as well. I was told that there are quite a few but I know of only one at the moment:
 
 In many Puranas, the tale of Aditi who wanted a child to slay Indra, a presiding deity is related. While the child was still in the foetus state, Indra entered Aditi's womb and killed the unborn child.
 
 Looking forward to finding learning about the views of other religions.

 1 Timothy 2:11-15:"A woman should learn in quietness and full submission. I do not permit a woman to teach or to have authority over a man; she must be silent..." 
 
 Ephesians 5:22-24: "Wives, submit to your husbands as to the Lord. For the husband is the head of the wife...wives should submit to their husbands in everything."
 
 1 Corinthians 14:34-35: "...women should remain silent in the churches. They are not allowed to speak, but must be in submission, as the Law says, If they want to inquire about something, they should ask their own husbands at home; for it is disgraceful for a woman to speak in the church." 
 
 1 Corinthians 11:3: "...Christ is the head of every man, and a husband the head of his wife, and the head of Christ is God."
 
 1 Corinthians 11:4-7 Any man who prays or prophesies with something on his head disgraces his head, but any woman who prays or prophesies with her head unveiled disgraces her head--it is one and the same thing as having her head shaved. For if a woman will not veil herself, then she should cut off her hair; but if it is disgraceful for a woman to have her hair cut off or to be shaved, she should wear a veil. For a man ought not to have his head veiled, since he is the image and reflection of God; but woman is the reflection of man.

Winston Smith

"And if men struggle with each other and strike a woman with child so that she has a miscarriage, yet there is no further injury, he shall surely be fined as the woman's husband may demand of him; and he shall pay as the judges decide. But if there is any further injury, then you shall appoint as a penalty life for life." (Exodus 21:22-23)
 Obviously this refers to the woman not to the foetus. If the mother miscarriages but suffers no other injury, regardless of whether the foetus dies or not, only a fine applies. 
 This quote also does not refer to abortion as we understand it today: an intentional assisted miscarriage.
